input.name: __VIEWSTATE

p.span: Governor Mike DeWine has extended his school closure order. As a result, Warrensville Heights City School District will be closed through the remainder of the 2019/20 academic school year. While the Governor’s executive order means that learning will not occur in a traditional school environment, teaching and learning for all Warrensville Heights City School District scholars will continue.

div.span:
UPDATE AS OF APRIL 20, 2020
Governor Mike DeWine has extended his school closure order. As a result, Warrensville Heights City School District will be closed through the remainder of the academic school year. While the Governor’s executive order means that learning will not occur in a traditional school environment, teaching and learning for all Warrensville Heights City School District scholars will continue.
During this time, there will be NO District sponsored athletics or activities. We have a committee charged to find ways to celebrate the WHHS Class of 2020 and plan for the continuation of important Senior milestones. More information will be forthcoming.
Our Mobile Meal program will still continue with delivery days on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.
Finally, it is critical that all District scholars login to our distance e-learning portals on a daily basis and complete assigned work. This is essential for their continued learning. The first three quarters will be used as a foundation/benchmark for the Quarter 4 grade and the Final Grade. Unless a scholar refuses to participate in their own learning, a scholar will not earn a lower grade for the fourth quarter than they earned for the third quarter of this year. For our WHHS Seniors (Grade 12), who have been working and learning digitally all year, you will be required to turn in work to earn their grade.
We will get through this together—One Team, One Vision, One Goal.

span.a: March 2, 2020: An Important Update on Coronavirus Preparedness

p.span:
The Coronavirus, referred to as COVID-2019, is a contagious illness that originated in Wuhan City, China, and is currently affecting a growing number of people in multiple countries worldwide. While health officials believe that the risk to the general American public remains low, the facts about the illness change daily and Warrensville Heights City School District is committed to keeping families informed.
Common symptoms of COVID-2019 include fever, shortness of breath, and cough. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) believes that, like the flu, COVID-19 is most often spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes. There have been reports that COVID-2019 can be spread from an infected person even if that person has no symptoms.

span.strong: What Warrensville Heights City School District is Doing:

p.span:
WHCSD is working diligently to ensure our schools are safe through active infection prevention and control. Additionally, our district is prepared to respond to any risk of COVID-19 in our schools, should it become necessary. We are in regular, direct communication with our schools, the Cuyahoga County Department of Health, Ohio Department of Health, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), for guidance and updates on recommended precautions. We will continue to keep families and staff informed directly through phone calls and emails. Now is a good time to update your emergency contact information.
The WHCSD Facilities team uses a rigorous disinfecting protocol to ensure that our schools are clean and safe for students, staff and families. Our custodial team has intensified their disinfecting protocol to include extra attention in common areas and frequently touched or shared surfaces. Read more on the preventive precautions we are taking to ensure the health and safety of our scholars, staff and community.

span.strong: Ohio Department of Health Call Center:

span.br: Licensed nurses and infectious disease experts are available to answer questions seven days a week, 9 am-8 pm. Call 1-833-4-ASK-ODH (1-833-427-5634).
